bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Paul B. Barringer, October 6, 1939

div1.p: Moran writes of a Thanksgiving he spent with Barringer in 1901, and then recounts his financial successes and failures after he left the University of Virginia Medical School.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Paul B. Barringer, October 6, 1939
div1.opener:
Havana, Cuba, Oct. 6, 1939.
Dr. Paul B. Barringer,
9 Oakhurst Circle,
University Post Office,
Charlottesville, Va.
My dear Dr. Barringer:
div1.p:
I am about to satisfy a desire I have had for “a month
of Sundays”, viz: to drop you a line or two. I am sure you would have
difficulty in recalling me and what I was like when I was at Virginia for a
sojourn entirely too brief to leave an impression. I well remember you,
however. You were most kind to me and would have helped me out, I am sure,
had the University been as well endowed in those days as it is today. You
may or may not recall that I slept in your house two nights during Thanks-
giving of 1901. I happened to be one of the few students at the University
who had no family or friends to visit. You went on a hunting or fishing
trip and you wanted some “grown-up” to be present in the house so that
Mrs. Barringer and the children might feel a little more secure. The con-
fidence and trust implied in your invitation I have always remembered and
appreciated. I felt very proud and highly honored.

Somewhere in your official or personal files there
should be a letter of introduction for me from Walter Reed. I am not
sure that I delivred the letter in person but if I did not, Major Reed
mailed it to you. As Dean of the Faculty, you were, to all intents and
purposes, President of the University. I am afraid that, as a student,
I was not very much of a success. Even in the dissecting room, where I
found myself very frequently as late as eleven o'clock at night, more than
once alone, studying arteries and nerves, my thoughts were given to specu-
lating on how I was to get through a four-year course in Medicine with the
all-too-slim amount I had on deposit in one of the Charlottesville banks.
I was unable to concentrate on my studies. When I invested one-half of
the amount I had in the bank in Grace Oil Company stock, I bid goodbye to
my medical education, without knowing it. Grace Oil Company, of Houston,
Texas, assured me that I would double or quadruple every dollar invested,
within six months. I read their full-page advertisement in Hearst's
yellow JOURNAL. I soon learned that the ground-floor concessions which
the promoters claimed to have in “Spindletop Heights” did not exist. The
company was formed by a band of swindlers. I happened, for the nonce, to
be “one of those born every minute”. Along came a Mr. Thomas P. Spencer,
looking for likely candidates leaving the University that year. He was
manager of the Metropolitan Office of the Travelers Insurance Company, in
New York City. You recommended me to him and he took me along with him.
I stayed with him for two years, not even earning my salt for the first
six months. At the end of the two years, I was on my way and the results
of my missionary work converted themselves into dividends. Then came an
offer from Gorgas for work in Panama as Sanitary Inspector. “The Call of
the Tropics”, of which I had a taste here in 1898-1900, was more than I
could resist. I threw up my contract with Travelers, one of the capital
errors of my life, and became a tropical tramp, so to speak. From that
point on, my life was far from humdrum. I was one of the pioneers on
the Panama Canal and had the great satisfaction of being one of the first
passengers on the first steamer that traversed the Canal from the Atlantic
to the Pacific end, 1904 men being given first choice by General Goethals.
Gorgas and the latter were my friends. Both were personal enemies and
while I know the cause I will not burden you with reciting it. Besides,
it is too long a story. After the Canal was finished, I launched into

the jewelry business in the City of Panama and was again “on my way”
when the United States declared war on Germany. I turned down a Major's
commission for service in the Canal Zone and instead went overseas as a
Captain in the Q. M. Corps. The War over, I went to Venezuela for The
Mercantile Bank of the Americas which “blew up” in 1921-22, just as I
was about to be appointed manager of its affiliate, The Mercantile Over-
seas Corporation, in Maracaibo. Had to start all over again, landing in
Mexico with the Mexican Trading Corporation, representing Sun Oil Company
and Firestone Tire & Rubber Company. The altitude being a little too
much for me, I made a bid for Cuba for Sun Oil Company products, forming
Compañia Sunoco de Cuba and of which I was half owner until Generals
Machado and Depression put me down and out during 1932 to 1934. Today,
Compañia Sunoco de Cuba is a 100% subsidiary of Sun Oil Company but they
have been most considerate with me. I manage the company and their
other interests in Cuba. Having no children, it matters little whether
I leave much of an estate or not. My life insurance will suffice to
provide for my better half as and when I may start on the road that has
no turning. In the meantime, I manage to live fairly comfortable. One
of the things I would have liked to be in position to do in past years
would have been to send some deserving young man to the University of
Virginia to graduate in Medicine, by way of making up for my own thwarted
ambition.

But please pardon me for imposing upon your time
and good nature with all this rambling. It is not fair and I am not sure
that you will not be bored through reading such a long and purposeless
letter. One of my outstanding faults, and I know it better than anyone
else, is to write long letters. My friends tell me they find them
interesting but I imagine they say so because they do not want to hurt
my feelings. Mr. Clemons will probably bear me out as to the long
letters. I sent one on its way to him a few days ago.

With my very kindest regards to you and yours,
I remain,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, John J. Moran John J. Moran.
From John J. Moran,
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.,
Avenida Menocal Nos. 455-457,
Havana, Cuba.
